repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body: Using `grl` in Normal mode over a Lua code block section will now run it. Mnemonic: "go run lua"(?). Could also be matched by a `grl` default binding to `codelens.run()` in the future. This commit also tidies up some of the docs, making previously invalid Lua code examples valid.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
To try it out, select the above code and source it with `:'<,'>lua` (or `grl`), then run this command in a :terminal buffer: >
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -165,8 +165,8 @@ directory indicated in the request. >lua
     end
   })
 
-To try it out, select the above code and source it with `:'<,'>lua`, then run
-this command in a :terminal buffer: >
+To try it out, select the above code and source it with `:'<,'>lua` (or just
+run it with `grl`), then run this command in a :terminal buffer: >

comment_data.body: we can also detect vimscript, right? then run it with `vim.cmd`
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -33,3 +33,46 @@ end, { buffer = 0, silent = true })
 
 vim.b.undo_ftplugin = (vim.b.undo_ftplugin or '') .. '\n exe "nunmap <buffer> gO"'
 vim.b.undo_ftplugin = vim.b.undo_ftplugin .. ' | call v:lua.vim.treesitter.stop()'
+
+-- Add "runnables" for lua code examples
+---@type table<integer, string>
+local codes = {}
+local tree = vim.treesitter.get_parser():parse()[1]
+local query = vim.treesitter.query.parse(
+  'vimdoc',
+  [[
+  (codeblock
+    (language) @_lang
+    .
+    (code) @code
+    (#eq? @_lang "lua"))
+]]
+)
+
+for _, match, _ in query:iter_matches(tree:root(), 0, 0, -1) do
+  for id, nodes in pairs(match) do
+    local name = query.captures[id]
+    local node = nodes[1]
+    local start, _, end_ = node:parent():range() --[[@as integer]]
+
+    if name == 'code' then
+      vim.api.nvim_buf_set_extmark(0, 1, start, 0, {
+        virt_text = { { 'Run with `grl`', 'LspCodeLens' } },
+      })
+      local code = vim.treesitter.get_node_text(node, 0)
+      for i = start, end_ do
+        codes[i] = code
+      end
+    end
+  end
+end
+
+vim.keymap.set('n', 'grl', function()
+  local pos = vim.api.nvim_win_get_cursor(0)[1]
+  local code = codes[pos]
+  if code then
+    vim.cmd.lua(code)

 vim.b.undo_ftplugin = vim.b.undo_ftplugin .. ' | call v:lua.vim.treesitter.stop()'

+-- Add "runnables" for Lua/Vimscript code examples.
+---@type table<integer, { lang: string, code: string }>

+local query = vim.treesitter.query.parse(
+  'vimdoc',
+  [[
+  (codeblock

+    .
+    (code) @code
+    (#any-of? @_lang "lua" "vim")
+    (#set! @code lang @_lang))
+]]
+)
+
+for _, match, metadata in query:iter_matches(tree:root(), 0, 0, -1) do
+  for id, nodes in pairs(match) do

+    local start, _, end_ = node:parent():range() --[[@as integer]]
+
+    if name == 'code' then
+      vim.api.nvim_buf_set_extmark(0, 1, start, 0, {
+        virt_text = { { 'Run with `yxx`', 'LspCodeLens' } },
+      })
+      local code = vim.treesitter.get_node_text(node, 0)
+      local lang_node = match[metadata[id].lang][1] --[[@as TSNode]]
+      local lang = vim.treesitter.get_node_text(lang_node, 0)
+      for i = start + 1, end_ do
+        code_blocks[i] = { lang = lang, code = code }
+      end
+    end
+  end
+end
+
+vim.keymap.set('n', 'yxx', function()

comment_regular_data.body:
Note: this could possibly be simplified (in the ftplugin) if we had a general "treesitter node" textobject (which would be generally useful).

Not a blocker, of course; this sort of "made-to-measure" code snippet is one of the powers of treesitter!

Not a blocker, but would be very nice to establish a generic "execute code" operation. https://github.com/tpope/vim-scriptease hints at `g=`. Other ideas: `yx`, `g?`, `g:`.

The DWIM version (`g==`, `yxx`, `g??`, `g::`) would run the "current injection", so targeting an explicit text object would not be needed.

Similar to how `gO` was first used in :help, we can use :help to establish this pattern for other contexts in the future.

I would suggest `yx` because it's low-friction (although maybe executing code should have some friction...). The implications for this immediate PR would simply be to replace `grl` with `yxx`.

> The DWIM version (g==, yxx, g??, g::) would run the "current injection", so targeting an explicit text object would not be needed.

Just to be clear, my comment was meant for "under the hood", not as a replacement for the mapping introduced here.

To document this, we can just add a blurb to `doc/various.txt` similar to what we did for `gO`, something like:

```
							*yxx*
yxx			Executes the current code block.

			Works in |help| buffers.
```

And also perhaps add a line here: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/b12b91c2743954dbe8599caa60e58e5d74aa4e76/runtime/doc/helphelp.txt#L194

I can reliably recreate a crash by running `yxx` on the last code block in `lua-guide` (I suspect it's not due to this PR but that this PR exposed it?)

```
/Users/dundargoc/programs/neovim/src/nvim/api/command.c:934:17: runtime error: member access within null pointer of type 'buf_T' (aka 'struct file_buffer')
    #0 0x000100e55ce4 in nvim_buf_del_user_command command.c:934
    #1 0x0001018eeeb8 in nlua_api_nvim_buf_del_user_command lua_api_c_bindings.generated.h:1993
    #2 0x0001028a1528 in lj_BC_FUNCC+0x28 (nvim:arm64+0x101a9d528)
    #3 0x0001028b7f2c in lua_pcall lj_api.c:1151
    #4 0x00010194e85c in nlua_typval_exec executor.c:1455
    #5 0x000101952274 in ex_lua executor.c:1681
    #6 0x000101614a10 in execute_cmd0 ex_docmd.c:1711
    #7 0x000101610624 in execute_cmd ex_docmd.c:1793
    #8 0x000100e40610 in nvim_cmd command.c:647
    #9 0x0001018ed710 in nlua_api_nvim_cmd lua_api_c_bindings.generated.h:1780
    #10 0x0001028a1528 in lj_BC_FUNCC+0x28 (nvim:arm64+0x101a9d528)
    #11 0x0001028b7f2c in lua_pcall lj_api.c:1151
    #12 0x000101951264 in nlua_call_ref_ctx executor.c:1593
    #13 0x000101950ccc in nlua_call_ref executor.c:1570
    #14 0x0001017b27b4 in map_execute_lua getchar.c:3205
    #15 0x000101c823b0 in nv_colon normal.c:3185
    #16 0x000101c6c10c in normal_execute normal.c:1244
    #17 0x00010226e3c4 in state_enter state.c:102
    #18 0x000101c4b840 in normal_enter normal.c:522
    #19 0x00010197f580 in main main.c:651
    #20 0x000182fec270  (<unknown module>)

SUMMARY: UndefinedBehaviorSanitizer: undefined-behavior /Users/dundargoc/programs/neovim/src/nvim/api/command.c:934:17 
```

More of a nitpick/not a blocker, but unsure how useful it is to indiscriminately encourage using `yxx` for all codeblocks when half of them don't work without previous context. Example:

```
>lua Run with `yxx`
    vim.keymap.set('n', '<Leader>pl1', require('plugin').action)
```

will just throw an error that "module plugin not found". Not a big deal though IMO, and something we can iterate on later on if needed.

Edit: although perhaps we can get away with saying that users can "interactively create errors via code docs" or something?

> unsure how useful it is to indiscriminately encourage using `yxx` for all codeblocks when half of them don't work without previous context. ... Not a big deal though IMO, and something we can iterate on later on if needed.

Yes we'll need to iterate on it. Similar to many other cases, these kinds of problems become more obvious/urgent once there is a driver behind them. Now that the code examples are "alive", their correctness matters more.

> I can reliably recreate a crash by running `yxx` on the last code block in `lua-guide`

Fixed in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/31908

So only remaining things are 

- docs
- `b:undo_ftplugin`
- bug: reloading a help file with `:edit` adds duplicate codelenses:
    - ![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/def044b4-039c-437f-8f13-5d7db13d3466)

> * `b:undo_ftplugin`
> * bug: reloading a help file with `:edit` adds duplicate codelenses:

These have now been addressed
We will probably want a test for this, but I'll merge it to start getting feedback. Thanks @ribru17 !
In a follow-up, we may want to call it out at the top of `lua-guide.txt` as well! (Sorry, just thought of that.)

And while I'm at it, the following produces an error:
```vim
    lua << EOF
      local tbl = {1, 2, 3}
      for k, v in ipairs(tbl) do
        print(v)
      end
    EOF
```

> Not a blocker, but would be very nice to establish a generic "execute code" operation. https://github.com/tpope/vim-scriptease hints at g=. Other ideas: yx, g?, g:.

I may discard `g?` from the options, as it is used for some plugins to open a help menu, in order to not collide with backwards search `?`.

> In a follow-up, we may want to call it out at the top of `lua-guide.txt` as well! (Sorry, just thought of that.)

Conversely, I find the ubiquitous virtual text hint a bit intrusive (and it may conflict with using line conceal for codeblock markers, if we go that route for vimdoc as well).

> I find the ubiquitous virtual text hint a bit intrusive

Yeah I expected that. Will need to think about an answer. OTOH, the current text is very minimal...

> And while I'm at it, the following produces an error:
> 
> ```viml
>     lua << EOF
>       local tbl = {1, 2, 3}
>       for k, v in ipairs(tbl) do
>         print(v)
>       end
>     EOF
> ```

Dedenting the code block fixes this error , ill look into a PR soon

Just wanted to give some feedback since there wasn't yet any discussion on it. I expected follow-up tweaking (and that is fine).

To expand on that (the "why"): If you look at more than two or three examples, it's repetitive, and the "visual noise" -- albeit admittedly small -- outweighs the perceived usefulness. (It would be different if this were a "click to run" icon, where it would have local use on every occurrence.)

On the third hand, it seems to me a perfect addition to the context menu (for people who use the mouse)!
Some kind of "hover" functionality; only showing the hint if the cursor is inside the code block for X seconds could be a less intrusive solution? Could also be perceived as more annoying though.
Yes, `CursorHold` for the current code block only could be an acceptable compromise (possibly with a tweaked message). Would still have the problem with concealed lines, though.

What is the mnemonic behind `yxx`? I keep seeing it as "yank special x" or something. Thankfully it's just for help files but I was wondering if the chosen mapping can have some more thoughts.

Initial ideas - `grc` ([g]o [r]un the [c]ursor / [c]urrent), `grb` ([g]o [r]un the [b]lock), or something like `grx` come to mind. I'd avoid anything `gx` prefixed because of course that already has a mapping.

> What is the mnemonic behind `yxx`? I keep seeing it as "yank special x" or something

"Execute", analogous to `gx`. "y" as a general-purpose prefix (like "g") is established by https://github.com/tpope/vim-unimpaired , and will be useful for other purposes in the future.

> `grc` `grb` `grx`

`gr` is owned by LSP.

> "y" is not a general-purpose prefix as it is a `y` operator. Creating Normal mode mapping that starts with it will introduce various issues with Opertor-pending mode mappings

Similar to the debate about `cr` https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/28634 , that problem needs to be fixed instead of disallowing operators as prefixes.

I'm open to `g=` though.

> > "y" is not a general-purpose prefix as it is a `y` operator. Creating Normal mode mapping that starts with it will introduce various issues with Opertor-pending mode mappings
> 
> Similar to the debate about `cr` #28634 , that problem needs to be fixed instead of disallowing operators as prefixes.

Adding mappings without first addressing issues they add is a slippery slope to technical debt (which tends to never be addressed in the end).

> I'm open to `g=` though.

The `g==` instead of `yxx` then? To possibly "reserve" `g=` prefix for later uses?

> which tends to never be addressed in the end

Complete nonsense. Keep that kind of FUD off the issue tracker.

> `g==` instead of `yxx` then? To possibly "reserve" `g=` prefix for later uses?

Yes, `g=` is an "operator" that acts on motions/objects. The "later uses" are simply drawing the rest of that owl.

Playing more with this feature, it seems to me (with admitted selection bias) that more snippets trigger an error than work -- this makes the blanket virtual text signal even more worthless (for lack of a better word; I don't want to say it is worthless, period; but one gets trained to ignore it because "it probably doesn't work anyway"). It would be better if there were a way to explicitly label known to be working examples; not sure how to actually do this in a reasonable manner, though...

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: feat(docs): run lua code examples with yxx
